Minimum/Maximum Step Placement-A newly appointed faculty member who has not had previous teaching experience and/ or verified occupational/vocational experience shall be placed on Step 1. Faculty members shall be placed on the salary schedule step based on their years of education service and occupational vocation experience
	 
8.6.1      Teaching Experience Placement 
For instructional experience and non-instructional experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university, faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1       0-3 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 2       4 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 3       5 years previous teaching/non- instructional
Step 4       6 or more years previous teaching/non-instructional
	 
8.6.2    Full-time Education Service Experience
For step placement, year-for-year credit will be allowed on the basis of one (1) increment for each year of verified experience as teacher, counselor, librarian, nurse or other faculty position experience not to exceed the equivalent of step 4.  A year experience is obtained by paid full-time educational service in an accredited secondary school or college or university. One (1) year of full-time teaching experience shall be defined as service rendered of no less than 75% of time and load during each semester of a previous qualifying school year. Employment as a teaching assistant or laboratory assistant will not be accepted as qualifying experience.  Teaching experience must be as “the teacher of record”.
	 
8.6.3    Credit of Previous Academic Adjunct Teaching Experience
Credit for academic adjunct paid-teaching experience shall be granted pro-rata based on the total teaching load taught by an instructor in the faculty member’s previous employment at an accredited secondary school, college or university.  The total credit allotted for previous academic adjunct experience will be rounded off to the nearest whole number.  An instructor may not be credited with more than one (1) year experience for service within any one (1)-school fiscal year.
	 
	 
8.6.4      Verified Occupational/Vocational Placement
For verified occupational/vocational experience faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1       0-4 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 2       5-6 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 3       7-8 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 4       9 or more full time years of occupational work experience
	 
8.6.5      Credit for Prior Teaching and Creditable Work Experience
	 
8.6.5.1       Creditable Service
For placement, creditable service can include a combination of teaching experience and directly related work-experience not to exceed placement on Step 4.  Faculty shall be given credit to a maximum of six (6) equivalent years prior teaching, non instructional counseling, librarian experience outside the District (placing the faculty at Step 4) for teaching experience in an accredited secondary school or college/university. Faculty shall be given credit up to a maximum of six (6) years of creditable work experience (placing faculty at Step 4). 
	 
8.6.5.2       Combination of Teaching and Creditable Work Experience
Faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows for verified creditable work experience and teaching experience:
	 
Step 1       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal 0-3 years
Step 2       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 4 years
Step 3       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 5 years
Step 4       Any combination of creditable teaching and work experience equal to 6 years or more
	 
	 
Article 9 Adjunct Faculty and Substitutes
	 
Adjunct Faculty members employed for adjunct service shall be placed on the adjunct salary schedule step based on their years of education service and occupational vocation experience

For teaching experience adjunct faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1       0-3 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 2       4 years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 3       5 or more years previous teaching/non-instructional
Step 4       6 or more years previous teaching/non-instructional
	 
9.6.2    Verified Occupational/Vocational Placement
For verified occupational/vocational experience adjunct faculty shall be placed on the salary schedule as follows:
	 
Step 1     0-4 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 2     5-6 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 3     7-8 full time years of occupational work experience
Step 4     9 or more full time years of occupational work experience

Faculty shall be given credit up to a maximum of six (6) years of creditable work experience (placing faculty at Step 4).

In December 2011, a solicitation for Employee Benefits Insurance Broker and Consulting Services proposal was issued to thirty-five (35) potential vendors identified by surveying other bay area community college districts and from vendors currently on the District's list of potential vendors.  Of the thirty-five (35) vendors, eight (8) submitted bids to the District.  The respondents were Alliant, AON, D/A Financial, EPIC, Gallagher, Jenkins, Keenan, and Wells Fargo.
	 
The eight (8) bids were evaluated by a committee that included the Director of Fiscal Services, the Vice Chancellor of Human Resources, a purchasing agent, CSEA representatives, FA representatives, MSCC representatives, and the District's Benefit Analyst.  Five (5) vendors (Alliant, AON, D/A Financial, EPIC, and Keenan) were selected to provide a presentation to the committee based upon the following criteria:  Capacity to Perform (35%), Pricing (35%), and References (30%).
	 
Alliant was unanimously picked by the committee to be recommended for award.  Alliant had the lowest price of all the vendors, had excellent references, and was deemed to have had the best all-around proposal and presentation.  Additionally, Alliant has put 25% of its fees at risk as part of a performance guarantee.

On Sunday, February 26, 2012, the District was to conduct a solar power tie in to connect our photovoltaic panels to our central plant. Evergreen Valley College conducted a major shutdown, closing 12 buildings and multiple portables starting at 6:00 a.m. After the solar power tie-in was completed, Gullo I did not come back online as two redundant breakers had failed to close due to an internal broken trip mechanism. Cupertino Electric was on-site and attempted to assist the District in remedying this issue late into the evening, but was unsuccessful.
	 
On Monday, February 27, 2012, Cupertino Electric continued to assist the District by attempting to close the internal broken trip mechanism, but was unsuccessful.  Cupertino Electric re-spliced the incoming power to eliminate one of the two failed breakers in the transformer. A refurbished breaker was located by Cupertino Electric, and Gullo I was back online at 4:15 p.m. 
	 
The District did not seek formal bids given that Cupertino Electric was present from the start of the solar power tie in. The power shutdown in Gullo I was an immediate health and safety concern for our students, staff and faculty as well as potential damage and danger to our property. Therefore, the District invoked California Public Contract Code Section 20654, which states that “In an emergency when any repairs, alterations, work or improvements is necessary to any facility of the college, or to permit the continuance of existing college classes, or to avoid danger to life or property, the board may by unanimous vote, with the approval of the county superintendent of schools … make a contract in writing or otherwise on behalf of the district for the performance of labor and furnishing of materials or supplies for the purpose without advertising for or inviting bids.” The District received approval from Dr. Charles Weis, Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools.
	 
Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees unanimously approve the contract to Cupertino Electric, Inc. in the amount of $15,652.40 for the emergency power shutdown at Gullo I remedied by the purchase and installation of a refurbished breaker "without advertising for or inviting bids" "to avoid the danger of life or property."

Each year, many community colleges project negative cash flows in some months and must engage in temporary borrowing in order to ensure that funds are available to meet payroll and other expenditures.  For many years the California Community College League has coordinated an effort to pool the cash needs of these districts by issuing one debt instrument for all districts.  This provides substantial savings in the cost of going to market with short-term debt instruments.  The cost of the Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note to the District is estimated to be approximately $200,000; however, will be partially offset by the short-term investment earnings that the District will realize while the cash is deposited in the County's investment pool.

The District entered into a contract with Harry L. Murphy, Inc. for $9,150 to install a moisture barrier and sheet flooring in the PE women's restroom at Evergreen Valley College. The agreement was ratified by the Board of Trustees March 13, 2012.
 
Subsequent to work commencement, unforeseen conditions caused three separate change orders that increased the cost beyond the bid threshold of $15,000 for public works projects. Attached is documentation provided by Harry L. Murphy, Inc. detailing the change orders that were necessary to properly install the floor in the PE women's restroom at Evergreen Valley College. California Public Contract Code Section 20659 does allow for change orders stating that "If any change or alteration of a contract governed by the provisions of this article is ordered by the governing board of the community college district, such change or alteration shall be specified in writing and the cost agreed upon between the governing board and the contractor. The board may authorize the contractor to proceed with performance of the change or alteration without the formality of securing bids, if the cost so agreed upon does not exceed the greater of:
          (a) The amount specified in Section 20651 or 20655, whichever is applicable to the original contract; or
          (b) Ten percent of the original contract price."
The change orders exceeded the aforementioned guidelines, causing the total cost of the contract to increase to $20,805.  
 
Adhering to the stipulation regarding change orders, as described in California Public Contract Code Section 20659, would have been disadvantageous as the conditions which required the change order were discovered after the removal of the existing floor.  Therefore it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the changes to the contract with Harry L. Murphy, Inc., bringing the total amount to $20,805.

At its meeting of April 12, 2011, the Board of Trustees awarded a contract with Perry-Smith, LLP for independent audit services in an amount not to exceed $77,850 for FY 2010-11, $77,850 for FY 2011-12, and $81,000 for FY 2012-13.  On November 1, 2011, Perry-Smith, LLP merged with Crowe Horwath, LLP.
	 
Attached is a list of the services and the cost of those services in relation to the contract amount.  The services that are the cause of the change order are as follows:
	 
District Audit:  The contract was for $50,500; however, the total cost was $60,000 (for a difference of $9,500) due to additional hours incurred assisting the District with the completion of the District's financial audit.
	 
District Foundation Audit and Tax Returns:  The contract was for $9,750; however, the total cost was $13,750 (for a difference of $4,000) due to additional hours incurred assisting the Foundation with the completion of the Foundation's financial audit.

State Chancellor's Office Required Certification of Attendance Reports:  This requirement was imposed by the State Chancellor's Office after the time of the Request for Proposal and was not included in the contract.  The cost for these services was $14,000.
	 
District's Request to Expand Scope of Audit of Attendance Reports:  The District requested an expanded scope of its historical attendance reporting to the State, which increased the cost of services by $21,053.

BACKGROUND
	 
On February 14, 2012, SJECCD Board of Trustees approved resolution 21412-4 in response to the aggressive timeline for the establishment of legislative mandates to implement the California Student Success Task Force Recommendations via the Seymour-Campbell Student Success Act of 2012.  Specifically, the Board recommended, within this resolution, that the state slow the legislative proposed timeline to allow for an impact study and to modify legislative language.  Ten days later, on February 24, 2012, SB 1456 (Lowenthal) was introduced as the first legislative action of the California Student Success Task Force. On March 28, the bill was amended (see attached) and placed on the legislative calendar.
	 
At the first meeting of the Board Committee on Student Success (February 21, 2012) staff was charged with a number of tasks, including the development and implementation of a legislative advocacy strategy to monitor and address student success related legislation. This item responds to that request. Ordinarily board action requires two readings. In this instance, however, legislative timelines associated with the introduction and passage of SB 1456 require immediate action for the following reasons:   
	 
April 11th:  Deadline for feedback on the amended bill to the Senate Education Committee.
	 
April 18th:  Introduction of SB 1456 to the Senate Education Committee meeting and Public Comment.  
	 
Note:  Representatives from the SJECCD Student Success Constituent Group have committed to present testimony and to represent the District’s position as approved. 
	 
We will continue to monitor, amend and adjust the District’s position as appropriate pending additional consultation with internal constituents and feedback provided by other Districts/Colleges.
